awd_titl_txt: CPS: Breakthrough: Collaborative Research: Securing Smart Grid by Understanding Communications Infrastructure Dependencies
awd_abstract_narration:
Smart grid includes two interdependent infrastructures: power transmission and distribution network, and the supporting telecommunications network. Complex interactions among these infrastructures lead to new pathways for attack and failure propagation that are currently not well understood. This innovative project takes a holistic multilevel approach to understand and characterize the interdependencies between these two infrastructures, and devise mechanisms to enhance their robustness. 

Specifically, the project has four goals.  The first goal is to understand the standardized smart grid communications protocols in depth and examine mechanisms to harden them. This is essential since the current protocols are notoriously easy to attack. The second goal is to ensure robustness in state estimation techniques since they form the basis for much of the analysis of smart grid. In particular, the project shall exploit a steganography-based approach to detect bad data and compromised devices. The third goal is to explore trust-based attack detection strategies that combine the secure state estimation with power flow models and software attestation to detect and isolate compromised components. The final goal is to study reconfiguration strategies that combine light-weight prediction models, stochastic decision processes, intentional islanding, and game theory techniques to mitigate the spreading of failures and the loss of load. A unique aspect of smart grid security that will be studied in this project is the critical importance of timeliness, and thus a tradeoff between effectiveness of the mechanisms and the overhead introduced. The project is expected to provide practical techniques for making the smart grid more robust against failures and attacks, and enable it to recover from large scale failures with less loss of capacity. The project will also train students in the multidisciplinary areas of power systems operation and design, networking protocols, and cyber-physical security.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals and outcomes of this collaborative project aiming to secure a smart grid, a cyber-physical system (CPS), include: (1) Identification of data integrity and availability attacks by organized adversaries in the advanced metering infrastructure (AMI) and phasor measurement units (PMUs) of a smart grid; (2) Development of a novel lightweight anomaly detection scheme for early indication of attack type, strength, and strategy with low false alarms and high accuracy, followed by a threat mitigation scheme to defend against changing attack context; (3) Development of trust scoring models to probabilistically identify smart meters compromised by an adversary to launch data integrity and omission attacks to cripple smart grid operations; (4) Design of information-theoretic classifiers to provide linearly separable trust scores that distinguish between compromised and honest meters with high degree of certainty and low error rates; and (5) validating the proposed models, frameworks and solutions with real datasets from smart meters and PMUs.

The broader impacts of this innovative project include research training and mentoring of a postdoctoral researcher who is now an assistant professor of computer science at Western Michigan University since fall 2018; two doctoral students receiving Ph.D. degrees in December 2021; and three undergraduate students – one of them already finished a master’s degree in computer science, another one is currently a graduate student in computer while the third one is currently pursuing a Ph.D. degree. Numerous high-quality papers were published in top tier journals and peer-reviewed conference proceedings. The project findings have been disseminated through a dedicated website, invited seminar talks, and keynote presentations at various conferences and workshops. The outcomes of this project also germinated the seeds of an NSF project leading to a US-Japan collaboration, and another NSF project on secure and trustworthy decision making in Internet of Things (IoT) involving multiple CPS domains.

The intellectual merit of the project is manyfold. A novel framework is proposed for lightweight anomaly detection in smart meters or PMUs launching stealthy data falsification (integrity) attacks. The framework is based on a newly defined stable invariant as the harmonic mean to arithmetic mean of the coarse-grained and fine-grained times series data corresponding to electricity consumption. This mathematically proven invariant remains stable under normal (non-attacking) conditions but shows sharp transitions at the onset of anomalous (attacking) scenarios. Another innovation is the development of a diversity index-based trust scoring model for identifying compromised smart meters that inject very low margins of data falsification under the control of a stealthy adversary aiming to incrementally accrue benefits. This problem is extremely challenging due to wide legitimate variation in both individual and aggregate trends in real world power consumption data, making such low margin attacks often unrecognizable. By drawing parallelism between the effects of data falsification attacks with shifting ecological balance of species and modifying the concept of Renyi Entropy and Hill's Diversity Entropy measures, the proposed novel data driven information-theoretic device (smart meter) classification framework identifies compromised meters launching low margins of data falsification attacks that blinds existing defense mechanisms. Extensive experimental studies with real-world power consumption data from smart meters and PMUs validate the efficacy of the proposed frameworks, models, and solutions.
